snippet: The building of Semiperm Housing, which serves single mothers and their children, allowed a developer to add 114,000 square feet to 15 Central Park West.
abstract: The Appraisal column; Semiperm Housing program on Upper West Side provides two to five years of housing and supportive services to homeless single mothers and their children; building shows some of trade-offs involved in building affordable housing, as developers who built it were allowed to add space to luxury building on 15 Central Park West in return, deal that is much harder to secure now that zoning bonuses and tax credits require both types of housing to be in closer proximity.
lead_paragraph: The building of Semiperm Housing, which serves single mothers and their children, allowed a developer to add 114,000 square feet to 15 Central Park West.

headline.print_headline: Helping the Homeless, and a Developer
headline.main: A Helping Hand for the Homeless Helps a Luxury Developer, Too
